definition: Brahms (name)/Johannes Brahms (1833-1897), German romantic composer
flourishing/prosperous/suddenly/abruptly
to pull/to play (a bowed instrument)/to drag/to draw/to chat
woman who looks after small children/(old) female tutor
(phonetic)/this
Slovakia/Slovak/abbr. for 斯洛伐克[Si1 luo4 fa2 ke4]

sentences.english: One Deutsches Volkslied by Jahannes Brahms of your own choice.
sentences.chinese: 自選一首勃拉姆斯的德國民謠。

sentences.english: The second chapter is mainly concerned with people's reevaluation of Brahmas after his death.
sentences.chinese: 第二章主要涉及勃拉姆斯去世後人們對他的重新評價。

sentences.english: The sound of the Brahms music surrounds them.
sentences.chinese: 而陪伴他們的是勃拉姆斯的音樂。

sentences.english: Brahms was heavily influenced by Beethoven.
sentences.chinese: 勃拉姆斯深受貝多芬的影響。

sentences.english: Brahms was one of the greatest representative of german classicalism .
sentences.chinese: 勃拉姆斯是德國古典主義最偉大的代表之一。

definition: Antonin Dvořák (1841-1904), Bohemian composer, author of nine symphonies including the New World symphony
Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart (1756-1791), Austrian composer
Hector Berlioz (1803-1869), French romantic composer, author of Symphonie Fantastique
Piotr Ilyich Tchaikowsky (1840-1893), Russian composer, composer of 6 symphonies and the opera Eugene Onegin
Tchaikovsky (1840-1893), Russian composer
Handel (name)/George Frideric Handel (1685-1759), German-born Baroque composer, naturalized British in 1727
Frederic Chopin or Fryderyk Franciszek Chopin (1810-1849), Polish pianist and composer
Ludwig van Beethoven (1770-1827), German composer
Alexander Scriabin (1872-1915), Russian composer and pianist
Claude Debussy (1862-1918), French composer
Niccolò Paganini (1782-1840), Italian violinist and composer
Modest Mussorgsky (1839-1881), Russian composer, composer of Pictures at an Exhibition
Mahler (name)/Gustav Mahler (1860-1911), Austrian composer
Rachmaninoff or Rachmaninov (name)/Sergei Rachmaninoff (1873-1943), Russian composer and pianist
pinyin: La1 he4 man4 ni2 nuo4 fu1
